intro: Rubus suberectus var. armatus, commonly known as the bristly blackberry, is a shrub native to the temperate regions of the northern hemisphere. It is characterized by its thorny stems and compound leaves with serrated edges. The plant produces small, aggregate fruits that are typically dark purple to black in color. It thrives in well-drained soils and prefers full sun to partial shade. This species is often found in woodland edges and disturbed areas, showcasing its adaptability to various environmental conditions.
